item.title: Adding structure later feels like a chore
item.description: Page rework In the structure now vs. later (uncertain payoff, regret), people often defer structure until later. For more details on that, see Why people prefer to structure later or not at all.

item.title: C- Current tools do not support flexible exploration and refactoring of structures as they inevitably evolve
item.description: First draft: - Predefining a system limits our ability to explore alternatives outside the current structure. This cascades into the decisions to be made while in the act of work – what folder to place the note in, what naming conventions to use, what metadata should be added, and on.

item.title: C- Hypertext enables communication with high information density
item.description: C- Compression is necessary for synthesis and hypertext facilitates compression. Andy Matuschak’s working notes, like a wiki, use hypertext to communicate in an information dense way.

item.title: C- Linked references are a smart default for related items
item.description: Assuming you’re not using aliases, a plain text search in Obsidian for "[page](page)" within quotations is functionally indistinguishable from the backlinks for that page.

item.title: C- People process complex information in multiple levels and stages of processing
item.description: When we’re exposed to new information, we have to ask questions and learn more before we feel confident in our understanding.

item.title: I don't want my tool to tell me how to think
item.description: Advanced tools can be seen as too opinionated. Opinionated tools for thought can feel restrictive at the point of entry, limiting the user’s ability to work at the speed of thought.

item.title: I- Enable composable queries to facilitate structure in hindsight
item.description: [If a page’s related items section is defined through a search term]( I- Populate the related items section through a search term), then we can think of the page title and its query as a key-value pair.

item.title: I- Populate the related items section through a search term
item.description: In the structure now vs. later (uncertain payoff, regret) tradeoff, people tend to [defer structuring until later]( Why people prefer to structure later or not at all) or not structure at all.

item.title: I- Provide Push and Pull as inline syntax to affect the related items section for a page
item.description: As mentioned on I- Replace the backlinks section of a page with a related items section, C- Linked references are a smart default for related items but are not a complete description of what is related.

item.title: I- Replace the backlinks section of a page with a related items section
item.description: We can I- Populate the related items section through a search term. Since C- Linked references are a smart default for related items, linked references should be the default search term so users don’t have to do additional manual work to make the related items section useful.

item.title: I- Search as a part of the primitive design
item.description: Authored By:: P- Rob Haisfield Currently in notebook: There are few things that are more expressive than a search.

item.title: I- Use search terms as the basis for other features
item.description: A sufficiently detailed search term can be the basis for other features. For example: I- Utilize search terms as the basis for user-defined subscriptions I- Utilize search terms as the basis for user-defined notifications I- Utilize search terms as the basis for conditional formatting

item.title: I- Utilize search terms as the basis for conditional formatting
item.description: This one is simple - if we can use search as the basis for other features, and we can [map some action onto all of the search results]( Q- How might we apply map filter reduce to notes and what other primitives are relevant to this domain).

item.title: I- Utilize search terms as the basis for user-defined notifications
item.description: In multiplayer applications that do not have native notifications like Roam, we noticed a compensatory pattern in user behavior. Essentially, they would come up with a convention for a special page link to indicate a mention (like [@ Rob Haisfield](@%20Rob%20Haisfield) or [mention: Rob Haisfield](mention:%20Rob%20Haisfield)), and then write two queries for seen and unseen mentions.

item.title: I- Utilize search terms as the basis for user-defined subscriptions
item.description: Piggybacking on [enabling composable queries to facilitate structure in hindsight]( I- Enable composable queries to facilitate structure in hindsight), people will be able to define a search term that outlines their interests, such that they will be able to see any time new items are added to the query.

item.title: If I’m thinking too hard about structure before I write the note, I forget what I was going to write down
item.description: The title says it all. We spoke with multiple participants who generate ideas constantly, and if they don’t write them down immediately, the idea disappears.

item.title: Interfaces for adjusting a query
item.description: tags: Q- What are powerful interfaces for entering information into a discourse graph Not all edits to the query have to be within the query editor.

item.title: My tooling gets in the way of working at the speed of thought
item.description: Structural affordances in current tools conflict with our desire to work at the speed of thought. People want to work at the speed of thought, but current tools don’t allow for this to occur when one’s aim is to reuse and build off past thoughts.

item.title: Synthesis is hard to do with people who don’t share context with you
item.description: An exciting hypothesis that motivates our work is that making discourse graphs widely available could accelerate human synthesis work, and thereby accelerate innovation and scientific discovery.
